bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 1, 1948

div1.p: Hench discusses items he is sending for the Hall of Fame ceremony. Of importance are: Finlay's first paper, fever charts, the Congressional Medal awarded to Reed, remains of Building No. 1, and yellow fever volunteer contracts.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 1, 1948
div1.opener:
April 1, 1948
Miss Bertha Lyons
Hall of Fame
1 Madison Avenue
New York, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
I regret that it has taken me this long to get you this material.
As I wrote you, I found it more scattered than I had thought. Much was in
my home, some in my bank box, some in the Clinic and some on exhibit at the
University of Virginia. But, thanks to you, I now have things in somewhat
better order.

Last night, in my final assembly of the material which we have dis-
cussed in our various letters, I found that I had been notably confused by
your letter of 12 March in which you listed your requests. Not realizing
that you were using numbers from two different letters of mine and believing
that your numbers were all from my general list, I had ordered certain pic-
tures and items which I now find you don't want. Some of the unwanted items
I have retained. I have sent a few others along, from which you can make your
selections. The Photographic Department in the Clinic helped copy some of
this material and printed some of the pictures but the last considerable
batch of prints were ordered by me at a time when the department was quite
busy and I had to take the order to be printed outside the Clinic; therefore,
the quality of some of the prints is not as good as that of others. Rather
than reprint anything, I am sending them all along and once you have made
your final choice, it won't be very difficult to supply you with either a
better or a larger print, an enlargement from some of the prints or perhaps
clearer or glossier prints. I was myself surprised to find that some of the
prints are too small for adequate representation in a published article and I
am just now realizing that some of the copies were made for me primarily for
slides and should be recopied for a more adequate representation in a printed
article or program.

list.head:
MATERIAL ENCLOSED
(See numbers in red pencil on the back of items.)
list.item:
1. Reed's birthplace - two photographs; one of the birthplace before restora-
tion and one after restoration. Colonel Siler wanted me to remind you that if
you publish the photo of the birthplace, it might be well to note in the title
that Reed's father and mother were occupying this little building only tem-
porarily. As I recall it, they had just moved to that neighborhood and the
parsonage which was being prepared for them burned down. Rather than delay
matters, they moved in and it was in this temporary, very modest little home
that Reed was born. His father and mother were actually economically con-
siderably above the “log cabin class”.
Miss Bertha Lyons
April 1, 1948

2. Photographs of Reed (boyhood to manhood). These are from the photographic
film strip “Health Heroes - Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever” put
out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company - 6 photos. I had advised you
to get these from the Metropolitan Life but my prints came out better than I
thought.

3. Cartoons and drawings depicting the horrors of yellow fever in the pre-Reed
era; 9 pages out of old magazines obtained by me from Bettmann Archives, New
York. The arrangements one has to make with the Bettmann Archives should be
understood if you plan to use of these. Technically, one gets material
from then at a price, for one publication only and one must credit the Bettmann
Archives. For $75. I “rented” the originals and had them copied here and am
allowed to use them in any non-scientific publication of mine. Technically I
am not allowed to give them to you to use and if you use any of them, I would
suggest that you write Doctor Bettmann telling him which once you plan to use,
telling him that I submitted these to you merely to be helpful and ask him of
the fee he would charge. I think it would be minimal, it should be. I would
strongly urge you to use one or two because the present generation has no idea
how horrible yellow fever was, thus they cannot evaluate Reed's contribution.

4. Finlay's first paper - the first and last page of the original paper in
Spanish, the first page of the English translation from Finlay's selected works
- 3 items. Although you will have Finlay represented in the Cornwell painting,
I do think it would be diplomatic to represent Finlay a little more than that
and either to reproduce his picture in smaller size perhaps, or to reproduce
this first paper because of the fact that Finlay's theory was absolutely correct
and it was that which Reed proved. You will notice that the beginning of Fin-
lay's paper in Spanish occupies the lower half of page 147; the end of the
paper occupied the upper half of page 169. You might wish to rearrange them
so as to show both halves together and those are from Analos de la Real Academia
de Crencias Medicas Finicas y Naturales de la Habana, Volume 18, 1881. If you
want enlarged picture of the first page of Finlay's work in English, I can have
this made.

5. Reed enroute to Cuba to begin the yellow fever work - two different views.
These pictures I got from Mrs. Reed. Photographically, they are not unusual
but the smaller one showing half length has only been published once that I
know of and so far as I know, the full length one has never been published.
As much as I “love” Walter Reed, one gets tired of the oft-published conven-
tional photograph of him and it is refreshing to see a new view, even if it
isn't photographically too excellent. The full length view is about the only
unpublished photograph of Reed that I have ever found and if you don't want
to use it it is quite all right as I will use it in some publication of mine.
As to the identification, Mrs. Blossom Reed has insisted that the pictures
were taken when he was enroute to Cuba to do the yellow work.

6. Camp Lazear - 6 photos. I think the larger ones are the best ones but as
you will see, I copied them from page 188, Report of the Surgeon General of
the Army to the Secretary of War for the Fiscal year ending June 30, 1901,
Washington, Government Printing Office, 1901. You can obtain larger, better
prints by writing to the U. S. Army Medical Museum (in the Surgeon General's
Library, Washington, D. C.) and asking for a copy of negative 40731 and 40732.
Miss Bertha Lyons
- 3 -
April 1, 1948
If you have to make a choice, I would suggest the latter print. The two
middle-sized blotchy once are unpublished snapshots taken by Doctor Agramonte
and given to me by his daughter. They merely have the merit of being now,
unpublished ones and the blotches add “authenticity”. The two small ones I
copied from Kelly's book on Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever.
They are the clearest of the lot but are not as comprehensive as the two
Army photos. Please note that the one small one, opposite page 146 of Kelly's
book, is mislabeled. It is not Building No. 1, the fomites building, but is
Building No. 2, the infected mosquito building.

7. The preliminary note - the first paper of Reed and his colleagues, 1 photo,
of the Philadelphia Medical Journal, October 7, 1900. I didn't rephotograph
the Journal, you may wish to do so. The significance of my photograph is
that it shows Mrs. Lazear's own copy of a reprint which she presented to me
and it alsy shows the copy owned by Lazear's mother, who remarried and her
signature is C. C. Sweitzer, meaning Caroline C. Sweitzer. You might prefer
to rephotograph the first page of this paper and you can, of course, have
this done at the New York Academy of Medicine.

8. Fever charts. The most important cases of experimental yellow fever, the
charts of Carroll, Dean (“Case XY”), Lazear's fatal case, two charts of Kissinger
and one of Moran - 6 in all. Carroll's was the first case of experimental
yellow fever and was produced by Lazear, not Reed; Dean's was the second and was
also produced by Lazear. Lazear was the third. These 3 cases were accomplished
while Reed was in Washington. Each has special significance but you may pre-
fer to reproduce the chart of Kissinger, which was Reed's first experimental
case and the first completely controlled experimental case in history. The
other three were not completely controlled. You will note two charts for
Kissinger. One is a photograph of the actual fever chart which is in my
possession. The other is the published chart as it appears in one of the Board's
papers, as autographed by Kissinger. Don't be fooled by the fact that the
charts don't look alike. In the smaller chart they seem to have charted
certain sub-normal temperatures that appear to have been omitted in the original
chart. Actually, as the case progressed, usually no chart was made from day
to day, they merely tabulated a record which was later charted. The latter
charts therefore were often made at one sitting and appear to be very neat.
However, some of the charts were actually charted from day to day and one
notes different handwriting from day to day.

9. The Congressional Medal. I enclose two photographs merely as samples.
The one is the photograph of Moran's medal, the other a photograph of Kissinger's
medal. You will be receiving from the University of Virginia probably a better
photograph of Reed's medal. The reason that Moran's medal doesn't show up as
clearly is that this is a photograph of a photograph whereas I actually photo-
graphed the Kissinger medal. It is interesting to note that it shows up nicer
with a black rather than a white background. I didn't notice this until last
night and if the University of Virginia sends you a photograph with a white
background and you wish otherwise, I think they would copy it on a black
background.

10. Reed's deathplace, which was in 1900 the U. S. Army General Hospital at
Washington Barracks, Washington, D. C. The building still stands but is now
used as quarters for non-commissioned officers and their families at the Army
War College grounds. He died in a room on the second floor, right side, near
where the fire escape now is. Until last year the place was officially called
Miss Bertha Lyons
- 4 -
April 1, 1948
the Army War College but in recent letters from Colonel Siler he has used
the name Fort Something-or-other, a name not familiar to me. If this
photograph is not adequate you can obtain a photograph by writing the
Commanding General, Army War College.

11. Remains of Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear. These were taken just last
month by me in Cuba. I enclose two pictures, one of the little building.
(I am on the right with Johnny Moran between me and Doctor Nogueira of
Havana). The other photograph shows the little smoke stack (in my possession)
in front of the photograph of the Building No. 1 as it now remains. It was
up through this actual smoke stack that the theory of infected bedding, etc.,
went.

12. Letter of Reed to Surgeon General Sternberg, July 24, 1900; complete
photostat, 8 pages; photograph 4 pages. I would suggest you use the last
page, page 8.

13. Letter of Reed to his wife, October 6, 1900; complete photostat of 6
pages. I suggest you consider pages 3, 4 and 5.

14. Letter of Reed to his wife, December 2 - 3, 1900; photostat of 4 pages,
photograph of 2 pages. I think this is a very good one as it mentions what the
Havana papers were calling him and his colleagues, namely, savages and bar-
barians.

15. Letter of Reed to his wife, December 18 - 19, 1900; photostat of 8 pages,
and envelope; photograph of 4 pages.

16. Letter of Reed to Sternberg, December 25 - 26, 1900. You will receive
the complete photostat of the complete letter from the University of Virginia.
I enclose only a fragment showing in Reed's handwriting a drawing of Building
No. 1, to compare with the enclosed drawings of Agramonte from his articles
in the Scientific Monthly, December 1915. You will notice that Reed's drawing
does not exactly compare with Agramonte's drawing, presumably made 15 years
later. The “mosquito building room” was added to the mosquito building after the
building was built. The only significant difference is that in Reed's letter
the arrangement of the entrance is a little different from that shown in
Agramonte's drawing.

17. Letter of Reed to his wife, the well known New Year's Eve letter of
December 31, 1900 - January 1, 1901. I enclose a set of glossy and one of
semi-glossy prints of the letter and the envelope and I have marked pages
a, b, c and d. You will probably receive photostats of the letter from the
University of Virginia. I sent you one set of prints of this letter before.
You ask for the complete letter with signature. It doesn't exist as such.
Remember that all of those letters were quite personal letters of Reed to his
wife and his very young daughter. They were never meant for publication or
for the perusal of others. Mrs. Reed was a kindly, sentimental woman and in
the bosom of his family, Major Reed responded with marked affection and sen-
timentality. They had pet names and nick names and family expressions which
appear throughout the letters. To maintain Reed's dignity no one should pub-
lish those parts of the letters, or at least some of these parts. I would
urge you, therefore, to omit the “family part” and only reproduce the portions
Miss Bertha Lyons
- 5 -
April 1, 1948
which concern the experiments. How would you like to have your own personal
letters published in cold print? I am sure you will understand my point and
it was because of this necessity that I asked you to get General Reed's per-
mission to let me lend you those letters. I will trust your good judgment
in this matter.

18. Letter of Reed to his wife, January 4, 1901. Photostat of envelope
and pages a to f; 6 pages and a duplicate of one page because the margin
is out off. May I suggest you consider page a, but this letter should be,
I think, censored as it criticizes Surgeon General Sternberg. Note that
on the envelope Blossom Reed pencilled the date January 8, 1901 but the
letter was actually postmarked January 4.

19. Letter of Reed to his wife, February 5, 1901. Photostat of 4 pages
and envelope; photograph of 4 pages. Consider pages 2 and 3. In finding
your way through these letters, please remember that the sheets were
folded. We unfolded the sheets for photostating and photographing. I
have marked the page numbers on the back.

20. Letter of Reed to Howard, the entomologist, January 13, 1901. Please
note Reed's human franity in that two weeks after New Years he was still
dating the letter 1900, but a pencilled note by Doctor Howard shows it was 1901 and as indicated
also by the surcharge on the front page of the letter. This is the well known
letter in which Reed acknowledges Howard's great help and outlines the value of
kerosene. Later, others claimed that Reed had no idea on how to get rid of
the mosquito. This letter is one of the chief arguments against that idea.

21. Editorial from the Washington Post, November 2, 1900. Note column 2
“The Mosquito Hypothesis”. This is wonderful and I would urge you to use
it. I suggest you use the first sentence and the last paragraph of the
editorial, either photographically or reproduce it in print. Remember that
by this date, November 2, Reed had given the preliminary note and had returned
to Cuba, and was erecting the experimental camp, but in Washington the idea
was considered “silly and nonsensical”.

22. Editorial, Washington Post, December 22, 1900. Column 2 “Still fumbling
with yellow fever”. I suggest you consider the use of the first and last
paragraphs of this editorial, either in photo or in print. About now Reed
was producing his first case of experimental yellow fever in the person of
Kissinger, a successful inoculation, but the Washington editor considered
the idea “ridiculous”.

23. English and Spanish versions of the contract between Reed and one of the
Spanish volunteers. Note that these photographs are from the Army Medical
Museum; through the courtesy of General Kean, I actually own one of these con-
tracts. If these photos are not suitable, I can photograph the one I have.

24. The isolation yellow fever hospital. The volunteers got experimental
yellow fever at Camp Lazear. They were immediately taken to these little
yellow fever shacks near the post hospital of Columbia Barracks where they
were cared for. It was in one of these little buildings that Lazear died.
This photograph is from a clipping posted in Mrs. Reed's scrap book concerning
her husband.
Miss Bertha Lyons
April 1, 1948

25. Five small photos of Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Agramonte and Finlay. All
from Kelly's book.

26. A photograph of Doctors Agramonte, Lazear and Carroll. This has only
been published once in the Connecticut Medical Journal. It was given to me
by Miss Agramonte. If you wish, we could enlarge just the center part.

27. Two small photographs of Cornwell's two preliminary oil sketches. These
quite beautiful sketches are in my possession. You are going to reproduce
Cornwell's final version. These preliminary versions show Finlay presenting
the mosquito eggs to the American Commission. I suspect you will not want to
reproduce them also but if you do, I can have the sketches photographed again.

28. Stamps in honor of Finlay, Reed and Gorgas, also rather recent cancellation
marks honoring Finlay. You may wish to reproduce a Reed stamp but if so, got
permission from the Post Office Department. Undoubtedly they will give it to
you and send you a nice reproduction.

29. Inside cover drawing of a meeting of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board
used in the book on Walter Reed by Laura Wood Hoper. If you wish to use it
I will send you Mrs. Hoper's address. I am sure the publisher would give
you permission to use it.

30. Detachment of the hospital corps at Columbia Barracks Post Hospital.
Many of this group were among the volunteers. An identifying list is enclosed.

div1.p:
I have analyzed the three programs you sent me and notice that in
general you have used only ten to twelve items. Usually five or six small
photographs, each one-half page; two large photographs each occupying one
page and two to four pages of autographed material. The following would be
my first choice and they are arranged in more or less historical sequence.

list.item: (a) Cornwell's painting, color plate.
(b) Reed's birthplace - 1/2 page.

(c) Photograph of Reed at 17 or in 1875. These might be small and you might get
two on 1/2 page.
(d) The cartoon of 1873 or of 1876 - 1/2 page.

(e) The drawing of New Orleans (1873) showing the streets abandoned except for
hearses, or the Newport view, 1899 - 1/2 page.
(f) The Finlay paper - 1/2 page.
(g) Reed enroute to Cuba - 1/2 page.
(h) Camp Lazear, Army negative 40732 - 1/2 page.
(i) The preliminary note of October 27; 1 page.
(j) Editorial, Washington Post, November 2 - 1/2 page.
(k) Reed's letter of December 2 - 3, 1 page. (Cut out the family part.)
(l) Kissinger's chart, the small autographed one - 1/2 page.

(m) The New Year's Eve letter. I forgot to mention that many of the letters
as saved by Mrs. Reed, indicate that she discarded the more personal
parts. Sometimes the first page or the first folder, sometimes the
last folder or last page were discarded. This was of course her
right and we cannot complain but that explains why the famous New
Year's Eve letter is not actually complete. The last page, with the
signature, was discarded.
Miss Bertha Lyons
April 1, 1948
(n) The Congressional Medal - 1/4 page.
(o) Walter Reed's deathplace.

(p) Photograph of Walter Reed Hospital. The one I have is inadequate. You
can get one by writing General Hench, the Commanding General.
(q) Building No. 1 as it now is, - 1/2 page.

div1.p:
I do hope that you can include the last photograph, the remains of
Building No. 1. Frankly, I have an ulterior motive. I had the privilege of
discovering this building after it had been lost for 40 years. I have been
successful in having the Cuban government designate the remains of this little
building as a “national monument”. Last month when I visited Cuba to propose
the erection of a Cuban-American medical museum to enclose this little building,
I was successful in a preliminary way and the Cuban government has just set
aside $50,000 as a starter. The Mayo Foundation is willing to contribute
to the fund and I am receptive to help from interested persons. I am not
asking you to participate in any way in this campaign but I do think it is
interesting to realize that the little building still remains. It sort of
brings the story up to date and it may pleasantly surprise some of those
present to realize the building still remains. Isn't it possible that some-
one might say, in effect, “For heavens sake, is that little building still
there? It should be preserved. Let's do something about it.” However, if
you decide not to include this, it is quite all right.

As a result of my confusion from your letter of 12 March, I have not
gotten for you photographs of the following items: (1) The Walter Reed Hos-
pital; (2) Reed's grave; (3) The laboratory notebook and (4) One of the early
letters from Reed to his fiancee showing his early interest in humanity. If
you still want any of the last three, let me know but I think you will have
much more than you can handle. I have withheld about 20 additional items which
I had originally planned to send you but they seem quite superfluous.

I would appreciate it if you would please return to me any or all of
this material when you have used it. Your publisher may need to make certain
notes on the back, instructions regarding cuts, etc., but even so, if you can
return it, I would appreciate it. If there is any other way in which I can
help, please let me know.

Incidentally, I hate to think that I can't be there and although I
must return from Washington after my talk there on May 12, my present plan is
to make a quick flying trip to your ceremony in New York, going and coming by
plane, just staying long enough for the ceremony. I would appreciate it if
you would let me know now what time the ceremony will be, how long it will last,
and approximately how long it would take for me to get from the airport in to
the ceremony and back again.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
